abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Road Flood
            Rehabilitation Project for Nepal was satisfactory. The
            project achieved its main objectives, its impact on
            institutional development has been substantial,
            sustainability is uncertain at this time, and both the Bank
            and Borrower performed satisfactorily. Several lessons can
            be learned from this project. First, maintenance management
            needs to be improved to ensure the sustainability of road
            improvements. Second, measures should be put in place for
            the control of land use within the road right-of-way and on
            slopes above and below the road where indiscriminate
            farming, quarrying, and irrigation could destabilize the
            slope and road structure. Third, while a number of project
            delays were outside the full control of either HMGN or IDA,
            others could have been avoided through decisive actions to
            expedite project execution. Fourth, efficient contract
            management can be enhanced through a number of measures,
            such as increased delegation of decision-making to the
            project manager. Finally, the introduction of
            bio-engineering works on a large scale to assist in the
            stabilization of hillsides was an important factor in the
            successful outcome of the rehabilitation works.
